etymology.description: 士 + 士 — two ritual axes, perhaps made of jade, one atop the other; duplication of 士; stylized into but unrelated to 土.
etymology.interpretation: Depicts two ceremonial implements stacked to form a tall, rectangular emblem associated with a jade scepter/tablet. The duplication emphasizes formality and stature, and its resemblance to 土 is coincidental rather than etymological.

examples.chinese: 他手持玉圭(他手持玉圭)，步入大殿(步入大殿)。
examples.english: He held a jade scepter and entered the great hall.

examples.chinese: 博物馆陈列着西周的青玉圭(博物館陳列著西周的青玉圭)。
examples.pinyin: Bówùguǎn chénlièzhe Xī Zhōu de qīngyù guī.
examples.english: The museum displays a green jade gui from the Western Zhou.

examples.chinese: 在古礼中(在古禮中)，圭象征权威与诚信(圭象徵權威與誠信)。
examples.pinyin: Zài gǔlǐ zhōng, guī xiàngzhēng quánwēi yǔ chéngxìn.
examples.english: In ancient rites, the gui symbolized authority and integrity.
